Write End(Set)\mathbf{End} (\mathbf{Set})End(Set) for the category of Set\mathbf{Set}Set-endofunctors and Poly\mathbf{Poly}Poly for the full subcategory of polynomials, and let P:End(Set)→SetP : \mathbf{End} (\mathbf{Set}) \to \mathbf{Set}P:End(Set)→Set be the evaluation-at-1 functor P(F)=F(1)P (F) = F (1)P(F)=F(1). PPP restricted to Poly\mathbf{Poly}Poly is a fibration, whose fibres are P−1(X)=(Set/X)opP^{-1} (X) = (\mathbf{Set} / X)^\mathrm{op}P−1(X)=(Set/X)op. I'm trying to figure out whether PPP on arbitrary endofunctors is also a fibration, and if so, what its fibres are

I have a candidate for cartesian lifting, which has to take a functor F:Set→SetF : \mathbf{Set} \to \mathbf{Set}F:Set→Set and a function f:X→F(1)f : X \to F(1)f:X→F(1) to a functor f∗(F):Set→Setf^* (F) : \mathbf{Set} \to \mathbf{Set}f∗(F):Set→Set with the property that f∗(F)(1)=Xf^* (F) (1) = Xf∗(F)(1)=X. But there's a lot of details I need to check, so I'm going to ask here in case anybody already knows the answer

For polynomials (ie. coproducts of representables) F(Y)=∑a:AYA′(a)F (Y) = \sum_{a : A} Y^{A' (a)}F(Y)=∑a:A​YA′(a), cartesian liftings are given by f∗(F)(Y)=∑x:XYA′(f(x))f^* (F) (Y) = \sum_{x : X} Y^{A' (f(x))}f∗(F)(Y)=∑x:X​YA′(f(x)). So the obvious thing to do is to try to replicate that but for general colimits of representables. As far as I can tell, the way to do this is to take the category of elements ∫F\int F∫F and its projection π:∫F→Set\pi : \int F \to \mathbf{Set}π:∫F→Set, and then F(Y)≅colimA:(∫F)opYπ(A)F (Y) \cong \mathrm{colim}_{A : (\int F)^\mathrm{op}} Y^{\pi (A)}F(Y)≅colimA:(∫F)op​Yπ(A) (where the colimit is over (∫F)op(\int F)^\mathrm{op}(∫F)op because we are talking about copresheaves as colimits of covariant representables instead of the more common version... but I'm not very confident at this bit)

Then colimits of presheaves are computed pointwise, so F(1)≅colimA:(∫F)op1≅π0((∫F)op)≅π0(∫F)F (1) \cong \mathrm{colim}_{A : (\int F)^\mathrm{op}} 1 \cong \pi_0 ((\int F)^\mathrm{op}) \cong \pi_0 (\int F)F(1)≅colimA:(∫F)op​1≅π0​((∫F)op)≅π0​(∫F), the set of connected components of ∫F\int F∫F

Next, I convinced myself that the connected components functor π0:Cat→Set\pi_0 : \mathbf{Cat} \to \mathbf{Set}π0​:Cat→Set is probably a fibration (but I haven't been able to find any reference for that, which makes me very suspcious). Namely, every category can be canonically decomposed as a coproduct of categories C=∑x:π0(C)Cx\mathcal C = \sum_{x : \pi_0 (\mathcal C)} \mathcal C_xC=∑x:π0​(C)​Cx​ where each Cx\mathcal C_xCx​ is connected, and then for a function f:X→π0(C)f : X \to \pi_0 (\mathcal C)f:X→π0​(C) there is an obvious definition of f∗(C)=∑x:XCf(x)f^* (\mathcal C) = \sum_{x : X} \mathcal C_{f (x)}f∗(C)=∑x:X​Cf(x)​

So, if I have a function f:X→F(1)≅π0(∫F)f : X \to F(1) \cong \pi_0 (\int F)f:X→F(1)≅π0​(∫F), I can form the category C=f∗((∫F)op)\mathcal C = f^* ((\int F)^\mathrm{op})C=f∗((∫F)op), whose set of connected components is XXX and which is equipped with a universal functor H:C→(∫F)opH : \mathcal C \to (\int F)^\mathrm{op}H:C→(∫F)op. And with all that I can finally write my candidate definition for cartesian lifting: f∗(F)(Y)=colimX:CYπ(H(X))f^* (F) (Y) = \mathrm{colim}_{X : \mathcal C} Y^{\pi (H (X))}f∗(F)(Y)=colimX:C​Yπ(H(X))

There's potentially many mistakes in all that, and even if everything works I also have no idea where I'd start with calculating the fibres, so I'm dumping it all here just in case somebody already knows the answer

One thing that's easy to notice is that if PPP is a fibration then its fibres must be locally large, since End(Set)\mathbf{End} (\mathbf{Set})End(Set) is. In fact the only way I know how to prove the magical fact that Poly\mathbf{Poly}Poly is locally small is to equip it with the fibration PPP and noticing that the fibres (Set/X)op(\mathbf{Set} / X)^\mathrm{op}(Set/X)op are all locally small
I know the answer is yes but I don't have a full write up of that (I have a partial write up in §6 here)

You might want to check Mordeijk and Joyal's paper(s) on open/étale maps. That fibration is related to those, when you write End(Set)=SetSetEnd(Set) = Set^{Set}End(Set)=SetSet you see why this is a topos-theoretic concept.
Specifically the functor SetC→SetSet^C \to SetSetC→Set given by evaluation at the terminal object of CCC has a special property I forgot the name of. Alas...

One thing that makes me slightly suspicious (I'm trying to poke holes before I commit to doing a whole load of calculation) is that Poly\mathbf{Poly}Poly is not a topos (and neither is the smaller full subcategory of functors of the form A×YBA \times Y^BA×YB, for which evaluation-at-1 is also a fibration), so this makes it sound like there's a strange coincidence where evaluation-at-1 can be a fibration for 2 different reasons

uhm I think the reason is the same, the fact it is not a topos is not clearly relevant. when I said topos-theoretic concept I didn't mean that it's exclusive to topoi, but that it is relevant for topoi.

As an aside, I'm a bit uneasy about the large limit taken here, but maybe one can make things nicer by restricting to small copreseheaves.
